thread.title: Cub notes: On Theo extension, magic acts, Schwarber catching
thread.title_full: Cub notes: On Theo extension, magic acts, Schwarber catching | Chicago Sun-Times

title: Cub notes: On Theo extension, magic acts, Schwarber catching
text:
There seems little drama over the status of team president Theo Epstein’s contract, which has just one year remaining.
“That’s not anywhere near the top of the list of priorities this winter,” Epstein said. “But I’m sure this winter at some point we’ll sit down and talk, not just about me but about a lot of the guys in the front office who contribute behind the scenes, about making sure this group can stay together for a while and finish what we started.”
Epstein’s original contract of five years, $18.5 million, was an industry benchmark – since surpassed last year when Andrew Friedman signed a five-year, $35 million deal to run the Dodgers’ baseball operations.
Cubs chairman Tom Ricketts recently has said he expects to get an extension done with Epstein.
Cubs business president Crane Kenney signed a five-year extension after the 2013 season, despite trailing the baseball side with a business plan that was designed to sync up with spending needs once the team became competitive.
Magic gone
Simon Winthrop, the magician who levitated the Cubs out of a five-game losing streak when he performed before a game in New York in June, gave an encore performance in the Cubs’ clubhouse before Wednesday’s must-win game against the Mets.
The second show was even more impressive and mind-blowing than the first, said one member of the audience. The ensuing four-run deficit in the first and 8-3 loss to the Mets, not so impressive.
“It was good,” Epstein said of the show. “Didn’t work. But it was good.”
Close enough to perfect
Slugger Kyle Schwarber, who hit 21 homers in 259 big-league at-bats, including playoffs, will continue to catch part-time and get a lot of playing time in the outfield next season, Epstein said.
The club still considers Schwarber a possible regular catcher at some point, even if the lack of regular games there might slow that development.
“Is it imperfect development if he’s doing both [positions]? I’d say it is,” Epstein said. “But when the alternative is sticking that kind of a bat in the minor leagues until he’s Johnny Bench defensively, I like the imperfect path.”
Notes: Right-hander Dan Haren, the veteran starter the Cubs acquired at the trade deadline, announced on his Twitter account after Wednesday night’s game what he had suggested since the trade: He is retiring. … Epstein on being the hot team in the playoffs (at times in Boston) and losing to the hot team (in this case the Mets): “It’s a great feeling when you’re the tidal wave. It’s not so great when you’re the dinghy.”
